title: What will be the closing price for aluminum per metric ton (MT) on 29 April 2022?
preds: Reviewing my forecasting approach to volatile underlying data. Glad I’m not in the commodities market at the moment.

With a day left until the deadline we are currently sitting at ~$3093.50. This would put it in the 5th bucket currently, with a few >6% downside to reach the 4th, or >3% upside from here.Despite the recent volatility I think it is pretty safe to think this should end up in the 5th bucket (95%). A 6% drop is a day seems pretty unlikely (1%) as it is just too big of a drop in a single day baring some black swan. A 3% rise could be possible with the large recent volatility, but again seems unlikely. I will leave this a 4% chance as it is significantly more likely than a 6% drop but still very unlikely.
Another question I'm going to have a lousy score on. Volatility.
Volatility has really pounced on commodities
Always so many factors that can turn on a dime. Always so much volatility.

Don’t look now but we’re in bin #5…prices also seem to be on a continued downward trend too.
The trend is clearly downwards shortterm
Over the past 2 months the trend of the price of aluminum has slowly been decreasing, but as of today the cost per metric ton is still in the $3,000
Feels like there could be some market headwinds this week. Might be discounting Bin5 here, but will wait to see if demand fears overcomes supply constraints
I have probably had this way too high for a while. We're like a 1.5% move away from being <3200
It seems to be holding steady just above 3200.

Spot is sitting at 3285, a small drop puts it below the 3200 bucket. Possibility looks massively under discounted.

It's not clear to me which way this will go. The price seems to be trending down. It's not clear whether it'll reach below 3200 by April 29 or not. Plus, there's enough volatility that it may bounce up or down enough to tip the result into one bin or the other.

Roughly 2 weeks to go. Currently at 3,236 after a drop of ~400 in three weeks. Magnesium is also moving lower. I mentioned the issue of volatility and rapid market corrections back on March 10th, but this recent drop makes <3,200 look more realistic within the time-frame.

Surprise dip in prices! Perhaps because demand in China may be falling because of lockdowns? The 3-month contract price is still 3385, but the derivative is negative.

forecast based on a Monte Carlo simulation
A little over 3 weeks left, Ukraine crisis shows no sign of ending, and energy costs / inflation won’t be abating in the next few weeks either, with very high confidence.

2022 started off with a low of 2807 (notionally removing buckets A, B, C); peak value in early March was 3848; since that peak, the low value has been 3258 (bucket E) - currently sitting 192 above the mid-march low point - based on currently trend, will likely remain above 3200 but may dip slightly below

After LME's closing up Ni trading, Al prices swiftly dropped but the minimum price didn't go below 3,340 USD/ton. Now they are back up and climbing. Adjusting until LME will resume Ni trading (date remains uncertain).
Plenty of volatility in the market. Support above 3260 may hold given the geopolitical landscape, but this question needs regular attention
Updating to be more cautious about the market's volatility thanks to @paulm 's analysis: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1413175.

Unprecedented circumstances have lead to the LME suspending trading in nickel after massive price spikes, which in turn has lead to >5% drops for a number of metals, including Al.  It looks like there will be increasing volatility for some time as margins have increased to help control the market. I’d think inventories will stay low as production is affected and demand will remain high; the auto industry in particular is now heavily reliant on Chinese and Russian supplies of various metals and we are reaching uncharted levels of opposing supply/demand constraints.  The likelihood is an increasing price for Al but market corrections could create dips below $3200.
https://www.reuters.com/business/lme-suspends-nickel-trading-day-after-prices-see-record-run-2022-03-08/

At the time of writing this forecast Aluminum is sitting at ~$3286.5. A historic high price, sitting just above the previous high levels from around 2008. The current high price is most likely explained by some combination of sanctions against Russia (Second largest Aluminum producing country after China at 6% of global production), reduced supply due to interruptions in production caused by COVID, High energy costs (Aluminum smelting is highly energy intensive, with energy costs accounting for more than a third of production costs), and increased demand in the auto and aerospace industry as military spending is being increased worldwide/COVID restrictions ease/Secular trend of the auto industry transitioning from steel to aluminum to increase fuel efficiency. Most of these causes are likely to remain in place if not get worse. As such I am assuming a base case of continued high prices, with the path of least resistance in the short term  being upwards. I think ultimately global energy prices will come down as one or a couple of OPEC+, Venezuela, and Iran are all viable options to try and tap to increase supply. Something that will be very politically motivating, especially in the US which is facing midterm elections this year.  This will ultimately drastically bring down the cost of aluminum as energy costs are a large component of the price. That said, I think April 29th is too short of a time frame to expect this to happen. I am leaving a 15% chance (11% $2,900-$3,200, 4% $2,300-$2,600) to cover the case where energy costs are resolved quicker than I expect

Huge %ge of Aluminum comes from Russia.  Price spiked on sanctions &c.  but may well come back as workarounds become apparent - ie China buys at lower prices and sells on ,  other aluminum miners step up production.

I agree with @paulm - it's indeed a volatile market, but the Russian invasion isn't likely to be repelled in the next two months so the Al prices will probably remain high. On the other hand, if Ukraine is occupied or it capitulates, sanctions will probably continue to be in place for Russia. Besides, even two weeks before the invasion (and one week before POTUS announced the Russian invasion was imminent) Al price was hovering around 3200 USD. Correction could be made by the end of the month depending on how events will evolve in Ukraine.

Markets can move quickly, and a late correction could be made at the end of April perhaps, but there are no clear signals why Al would move lower, and continuing pressures which could push it even higher. The likelihood of the invasion in Ukraine being over within a few weeks sadly still looks very remote, and the global fallout suggests prices will remain at an exceptionally high level for some time.
The biggest drop we've seen since mid-2020. We're almost at the point where a 20% drop would still keep us above 3,200. And aluminum is spiking because of the Russian war. So I'm updating way up.

Aluminum prices have now spiked to over $3700/ton.
Chances are quite high that Ukraine will not resolve soon, so associated high uncertainty in future geopolitical / market conditions and energy supply chains will remain, especially with respect to how China plays into things. (Even if Russia manages to take Kiev, this will very probably not be the end of major combat throughout the country). At the same time, COVID impacts also keep falling world-wide, so every reason to expect high demand going forward. Pretty hard to see prices falling significantly in the remaining timeframe. Oh yeah, and then there’s also inflation.

3200+  55 =>  58  
Oil up, other metals up, Fed raises still on table as inflation in general raises.
Currently over $3,400 and with more uncertainties going forward, putting higher probability in this bin.

Now that the world has become even less stable and more dangerous (thanks but no thanks, Vladimir), supply uncertainty plus inflation plus growing/pent up demand all seem to be pointing at a bin #6 outcome. Short remaining timeframe also contributing to my forecast confidence. 
It sure was hard for me to foresee this state of affairs just a couple of months ago. But I guess that when we’re forecasting correctly, we should expect to see big surprises 5-10% of the time…
Rotating higher based on current market price.
Ukraine crisis and Nord Stream 2 pipeline suspended; continuing volatility and pressure on energy markets are likely to push prices higher in the short term, and perhaps beyond May...

I think the Ukraine invasion will have an impact on this.

Projected supply deficits for 2022, high electricity costs, and pent up demand due to semiconductor shortages in 2021 could keep prices elevated
Moving up based on recent price.

The price has risen 24% in the past six months to $3,100 per metric ton, the highest in a decade
Rising energy costs, a significant expense in aluminum manufacturing, have led plants in Europe and China to close
Morgan Stanley estimates aluminum supply could fall 1 million tons short of demand in 2022
Also: A conflict between Ukraine and Russia, one of the world's largest aluminum producers, could make matters worse. Insider's take: A London commodities firm told the paper it sees aluminum prices becoming "a lot more volatile" and eventually rising above $4,000 per ton.
Adjusting for continued high prices. Aluminum is actually about to jump into bin #6! And I see no reason why prices wouldn’t stay high.
April Futures contract can give some assistance in the forecasting efforts.

The situation with Russia and Ukraine may cause prices to rise an extra bit, too.
Bloomberg, Jan 19: "lcoa Corp., the largest U.S. aluminum producer, warned investors Wednesday that any conflict between Russia and Ukraine could have an impact on the global market for the metal. Chief Executive Officer Roy Harvey said any kind of aggression could have an impact to supply coming out of Russia, the world’s second-largest aluminum producer. It could also cause a rise in energy prices, which would have a knock-on effect to the aluminum industry given the high energy consumption needed to make the metal. Responding to a question about what risks the industry would face if a conflict arose, Harvey said it could disrupt demand as well. “That can very quickly impact the supply,” Harvey said in a call with analysts. ... Russia accounted for about 3.6 million metric tons of aluminum production in 2020, tying it with India as the second-largest producer in the world, according to the U.S. Geological Survey."
https://www.yahoo.com/now/alcoa-warns-russia-ukraine-conflict-233508303.html

Upping the highest just a smidge.
Commodities inflation is pressing across the board

Seems like the chances might be higher than I previously thought that Aluminum prices could be higher for longer, although a reversion to longer-term price trends still remains quite likely as well. https://www.mining.com/web/aluminum-price-climbs-with-output-facing-pressure-in-europe-china/ https://oilprice.com/Metals/Gold/Soaring-Natural-Gas-Prices-Are-Weighing-On-Global-Aluminum-Production.amp.html https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/markets/commodities/aluminium-prices-may-rule-firm-on-volatile-energy-market/article64905502.ece/amp/
Higher energy prices in Europe and elsewhere will likely have some bullish impact on this market.

Shuffling higher buckets a little further upwards, in line with the opinion that inflationary pressure will only begin to resolve by mid year at the earliest.  And even if this is the case, I believe the price for a three month futures contract will not shift to below that of the cash price until long after the inflation is under control.

i was expecting a steady climb through February and slower reversal or corrections down during March or April. 
So all as expected so far, except I don't know if and how far the downward corrections will be, so I'm adding a little to the top bins as insurance.

Omicron has been detected in Henan province, which is #2 in aluminum output in China, which is the world's largest producer. If Omicron is not brought under control soon, I think we might start to see another price spike, as I think we can expect China to lock down wherever it spreads.
https://www.globaltimes.cn/page/202201/1245573.shtml#.Ydw-B6wYcfU.twitter
Pretty big climes since mid Dec after a month of stability. Could be a big few months going into Northern Hemisphere spring. Could be lots of restrictions including power.

This is essentially voodoo, but we're now pretty much on track for the previous trend to continue instead of bouncing around between 2600 and 2900, so I'm reversing my confidence in the buckets here and incrementing the 3200+ bucket a little.

Supply concerns arising from multiple simultaneous power generation issues (renewables / coal in Europe / Asia respectively) seem to be combining to drive the current price jump above the longer term “background trend”. Adjusting forecast to account for a slightly higher chance of persistent issues in this space keeping prices higher for longer (bin #5 or much less likely, even bin #6). My most likely scenario is still a price drop back into bin #4 (long-term trend) at some point before the Question ends. https://www.reuters.com/markets/europe/copper-prices-slip-dollar-strength-rising-omicron-cases-weigh-2022-01-04/

I think higher bins are more likely based on underlying trends during the pandemic. I would hope that winter-related power shortages/power price increases/coal price increases will resolve within the forecast period, but as production has been cut and stocks continue to fall, I expect prices to remain on the high end of the spectrum during the forecast period. Nonetheless, I'm increasing my forecast on the bottom 2 bins because volatility happens. I thought I'd also raise another potential issue: what happens if Omicron starts spreading in China? I don't think there is a big risk of this happening, as the Chinese government is doing everything possible to prevent its spread. But Omicron is one of the most contagious viruses the world has ever seen. It likely causes more severe disease than the ancestral variant, too. If it were to spread within the relatively immunologically naive population of China, where somewhere probably over 50% of the population is fully vaccinated with a vaccine that has substantially lower efficacy than vaccines used in the US and W Europe, the effects could be catastrophic for both the Chinese people and the Chinese economy. Similarly, stringent lockdowns to prevent Covid spread, as in Xi'an, could cause large disruptions. I think these are low-risk high-consequence scenarios for this question that would both push prices up by leading to decreased production and/or movement of goods.

I still think the upward trend seen from May 2020 to Aug 2021 will resume in 2022 and continue to gradually slow down. Al ended 2021 at 2807.5, about exactly where it would be if the 2021 trend present through Aug 2021 continued, had the Chinese energy crisis of the fall not happened. If that trend continued, Al should be at about exactly $3200 at the end of April 2022. Things that may upset that trend include decreased demand for Al for construction in China, temporary energy shortages particularly in China, and the effects of the Omicron wave worldwide. I think construction trends in China may tip Al into bin 5, so I place the most weight there, but I could picture either bin 4 or 6 happening almost as easily. Given that there are a lot of upward pressures on Al and that prices haven't been <$2k since the beginning of Feb 2021, I think bin 1 is extremely unlikely. I think bin 2 is also very unlikely, and bin 3 fairly unlikely, for similar reasons. But the index can be so volatile that I'll leave all possibilities on the table. The crowd strongly favors bin 4 over bins 3 or 5, but I can't forecast such a strong preference at this time given that the index can rise or fall 2 bins in a matter of weeks. And I don't think bin 6 should be ruled out, as prices could end up just over $3200, for instance.

Still in line with forecast rationale from November 5th
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1351265

Despite a fall from the 3,229 peak in October, aluminum futures ended the year on an upswing. Several factors out of China contribute to a positive trend: smelters with own power plants face rising coal costs [1], some of those reliant on the grid find their preferential electricity pricing withdrawn - including in Xinjiang, the second-largest domestic primary aluminum producer [2]. Moreover, all smelters have been presented with production ceilings, and these have also happened for magnesium - a critical input for most primary aluminum production [3] [4].  As a result, Chinese aluminum prices rose above the rest of the world, triggering an import wave that saw the previous yearly import record beaten by 10% in just 11 months [5]. Because these higher prices were caused by structural (or, at the very least, medium-term) factors, I feel inclined to believe the trend will be robust and continue until the closing date. This also supports the view that already in 2022 a global "surplus" of aluminum may be a relic of the past [6], though this may play out later in the year, as decrease in Chinese demand may balance the load. I *think* there is room for energy costs for EU smelters [7] to drop meaningfully by the closing date, but it is unclear how much this could affect the final price. Despite loud proclamations, EU ETS reform does not seem to be on the table for heavy industry in the examined time period.  A very simple extrapolation from the 2021 trend would see end of April 3M futures prices at just over 3,000 - quite safely in bucket 5. Based on continued demand and the Chinese trends, it would seem wise not to undervalue this bucket, which the crowd seems to be doing at the moment. The criticality of aluminum in both construction and automotive (esp. EVs) diversifies its uses/diffuses risk. While it may seem that greater attention must be paid to recycling [8], with the drive for quality in both construction and EVs, it doesn’t seem to me at this point that recycling would be in a position to stop or reverse the price trends on its own.  Exogenous risk: Australia, Guinea, China, Brazil, and Indonesia were responsible for over 94% of both world bauxite supply and alumina refinery production in 2020 [9]. With regards to Australian and Indonesian supply, I could not identify any potential upsets in early 2022 that would threaten this, as the latter has already expressed its intention to stop bauxite exports in 2022 [10]. As noted previously, price pressure from China will more notably emerge due to the continuation of the factors above. Elections in Brazil are not happening until way past the closing date, being scheduled for October.  However, Guinea is number 2 for Bauxite mining, and saw a coup in Sept 2021. The military junta currently ruling the country "temporarily" has yet to outline a timetable for elections and restoration of civilian rule. If nearby Mali is anything to go by, this will not happen for some further time, and ECOWAS will soon start issuing further sanctions - they signaled they would like to see elections by March [11]. Even small disruptions in production - but more likely logistics - may drive futures upwards in the time period in question. Already back in September, news of the coup itself impacted futures even stronger than spot markets. By the end of April, I can see most if not all of the factors driving prices slowly upwards still influencing the futures. While the energy crunch in China will not be as drastic, I would not expect regulation to be stripped back, as the state will be keen to consolidate hard-won gains on the carbon budget front. Shipping will still be a pain, and if the past two years are anything to go by, we will be headed into the hottest months for EU industry [12]. New  production capacity is  planned for 2022, but it does not seem that it would be a massive game-changer in the time-frame required.
In conclusion, I think there is sufficient reasons to go against the crowd and put a decent stake on bin 5. Bins 1 and 6 are extremely improbable given the structure for aluminum demand. Bin 2 is reasonably the "aluminum goes bust" scenario, yet still unlikely. For now, I am sticking with escalating odds towards bin 5,  with the main signals outside of China and automotive demand/shipping issues/energy prices being developments in Guinea, the opening of new smelters which push us towards bin 4 [1], and any accidents/strikes in existing smelters. 
-----
Side-note: EU imposed significant duties on aluminum converter foil from China in December 2021 [13]. Could this have any effect in the aftermath of a relaxed China aluminum market? Could not find any leads to further investigate this, but could be interesting to check in on later. [1] https://www.mining.com/web/carbon-brakes-aluminum-supply-response-to-booming-prices/
[2] https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/metals/102021-cost-pressures-mount-for-chinas-aluminum-smelters-as-regions-end-discount-power-deals
[3] https://www.supplychaindive.com/news/aluminum-makers-magnesium-shortage/608851/
[4] https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/backstories/1838/
[5] https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/china-aluminium-imports-hit-annual-record-high-in-just-11-months
[6] https://www.bloomberg.com/professional/blog/aluminum-supply-continues-to-decline-while-demand-for-the-metal-and-raw-material-continue-to-grow/
[7] https://oilprice.com/Metals/Gold/Soaring-Natural-Gas-Prices-Are-Weighing-On-Global-Aluminum-Production.html
[8] https://www.wastedive.com/news/aluminum-recycling-ubc-supply-chain-china-beer/608685/
[9] https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2021/mcs2021-bauxite-alumina.pdf
[10] https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/metals/112521-indonesias-bauxite-export-ban-to-have-limited-impact-on-china-supply
[11] https://www.africanews.com/2021/09/28/guinea-junta-unveils-charter-for-civilian-transition//
[12] https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/2995521/11563407/4-14122021-+AP-EN.pdf/9bbafa7c-ea3e-85af-626c-c458d2eeacf7?t=1639419332744
[13] https://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/press/index.cfm?id=234

External forecasts appear to range from 2,100-2,600 (IMF, World Bank, ISA) with most setting between 2,400-2,500. Most recent futures contracts for May 2022 I could find (thought might be stale) settled in at 2,493. Since 2005, equilibrium has been around 1,800-2,200, though current pace of inflation, supply chain issues and falling output from China will likely keep it above historic average, at least through April 2022. With that said, Fed action and potential interest rate movement will likely keep it in reined in compared to current level >2,700.
Adjusting lower because of Omicron uncertainty.

Passage of time.
Prices are currently scraping the bottom of bin #4, and we have a general expectation for a moderately slow upward price trend as the world economy recovers from Delta/Omicron. My “eyeball” fit to the longer term price trends over the past ~year or so suggests the ultimate outcome will most likely be scraping the top of bin #4, if current trends continue. Gradually, the time available for new surprises is diminishing, but it’s still far too early to get too confident about the outcome.
Omicron variant will have little long term impact on economic recovery

Okay, so the first thing to know is that the trend in aluminum prices has actually been fairly steadily upward since May 2020. Yes, between August and October of this year it spiked from ~2500 to ~3100. So whatever is happening is probably either structural or pandemic-related, and not something new to 2021. I'm not seeing any great justification for why those price rises began, other than just demand outstripping supply in the face of high shipping costs. I don't think that electricity rationing in China really has anything to do with this, so for now I will just model this. We're looking at 3% growth monthly, on average, since May 2020, with a roughly linear trend. It looks like about 90% of the time, prices stay within a range of about $300 in either direction. So I'll just project growth as linear and model normally. That gives 17%, 68%, 15% for the range starting at 2600. That seems wrong. What if we model the equivalent month-on-month increase and say, hey, suppose there's a 20% chance that things will just go negative? So this time I model a normal(0.03, 0.01) monthly growth with a 20% chance of the growth sign turning the opposite direction in any given month. That gives .....
Since commodities are as leveraged as stocks, at this point it is a gamble to forescast.
The trend is upward, and inflation will encourage it.  Demand should also increase.  But Al is too much of a staple to have dramatic shifts.
Much of the increase in 2021 was due to the rebound of the global economy from 2020. This rate of increase is not sustainable, so price trends should level off in 2022.
thr LME future expiring 20 Apr 2022 is currently trading at 2716.75.  the May future at 2714.25.
The recovery seems likely to continue, putting pressure on resources
inflation will keep growing.Supply can not recover in short time.
All commodities will get expensive, but aluminum will be in high demand for space and tech industries.

With all the pent up demand for products containing aluminum, barring some new catastrophe, I don't think it's likely that prices will be lower on April 29, 2022 than they are now.

Looks like China is doing everything it can to maximize near-term coal supply, thus setting the stage for more adequate electricity for people and manufacturing. This is presumably the cause of the big recent slump in aluminum prices. I am expecting prices to stabilize somewhere in bin #3 or #4, based on the apparent 2Q-3Q “steady state” price levels seen earlier this year. https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/28/business/energy-environment/china-coal-climate.html
In honor of @paulm's persuasive abilities and recognizing that my forecasts can be too pessimistic, I'm assigning a bit more weight to lower bins.

Current price 2,550. 
I find these futures markets difficult, as there are so many influencing factors, but here are a few that I think will affect key trends: Coal prices have a significant influence on aluminium production cost: https://www.reuters.com/article/global-metals-idUSL1N2RN0Z2
Reuters: 'Aluminium smelting is energy-intensive and up to 40% of the metal’s (Al) production costs in China could be accounted for by power'. China is a major global producer of coal, and it's intervention in spot thermal coal prices has recently lead to a significant easing of Al prices as a consequence. So China will play a big role by managing their energy crisis via coal and Al. The link with coal is shown here:
https://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3151710/chinas-power-crisis-why-it-happening-how-bad-it-and-what-if?module=perpetual_scroll&pgtype=article&campaign=3151710 Then we've got Magnesium, where shortages could heavily affect the supply chain: https://www.reuters.com/article/ousivMolt/idUSKBN2HC19Y
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-14/aluminum-makers-sound-the-alarm-about-u-s-magnesium-shortage
Mg counts for about 5% of higher grade light weight aluminium, used predominantly in the auto industry, aerospace and drinks canning (although 65-70% of the canning industry is recycled).  Mg prices have spiked massively due to production shortages, again from China, and pent up demand from the auto industry (EV markets in particular) and construction look likely to put continued pressure on the supply side. But will Mg availability issues push things higher still or lower? If Mg supplies run out the price of Al could fall in response to the whole supply chain slowdown. Over 95% of EU demands (and 85% global) for Mg are supplied by China - almost total dependancy - and China has all but stopped supply since September, leading to another potential crisis in the EU if stocks run out end of November. This threat means that EU industry is already heavily engaged with China to avert further problems,  which may reduce the longer-term risk:
https://www.european-aluminium.eu/media/3285/2021-10-22-cross-industry-statement_magnesium-supply-crisis-in-europe_final.pdf
But the issue is cost, not the element itself, which is still abundant (the third most plentiful metal). So while there will be increasing pressure on pricing through the term of the question I think this will be capped by China's management of coal and its energy crisis, perhaps by US and other production (although Matalco Inc. in the US may ration delivery in 2021), along with a possible supply-chain slowdown that could cool prices. Year low of 1,900 and high of 3,171. Prices aren't seasonal. I'm keeping a broad view and a wide spread for now, but not expecting a new peak within the time frame.

Primary global production of Aluminium is around 65mn tonnes out of which China is 56% (approx)
https://international-aluminium.org/statistics/primary-aluminium-production/ Power cost accounts for 30% of Aluminium`s cost of production. (In a steady state i guess this must be a few percentage points lower as this is from the latest Alcoa presentation where power costs are already elevated)
https://investors.alcoa.com/events-and-presentations/presentations/  With the supply cuts continuing in China (around 2.3mn tonnes so far is what i could gather) there is expected to be a deficit in supply for a long time
https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:hJ5AgPXPedUJ:https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-07-27/inflation-comes-for-aluminum-as-the-everywhere-metal-surges+&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=in At some point demand will start getting impacted, Or if there were to  be a credit event (low probability for now as i dont see credit spreads widening anywhere) then demand could see a sharp impact.(Keeping a low probability towards the lower bins for that possibility as of now)

Well, Bloomberg is currently showing LME ALUMINUM 3MO at $2746.5/ton, and falling. I also see that in just this past month, prices have fluctuated between bins 4-6 (~$600/ton) so it could be quite possible to get the big-picture trends right for this question, and yet still lose out in forecasting accuracy on the day, because of large short term fluctuations. Cool. I’ll start out correspondingly. Even so, recent historical price data suggests that under both status quo or escalating price scenarios, the first two bins would be much less likely. That being said, bin 1 prices were last seen slightly less than a year ago, so this fairly “flat” initial forecast might be considered too biased towards the higher bins. But I am too partial to the supply-limited increasing price outlook storylines to resist. The fairly short timeframe makes this leap perhaps a bit more defensible.

@m_soegaard made me think a bit more about whether and to what extent the 2020-21 upward trend would continue. I don't currently see why prices won't continue to increase, especially with pent-up demand for vehicles, whose production uses about 1/4 of global aluminum supplies. Construction gets another 25%, and that doesn't seem to be slowing down. In short, if demand or all sorts of goods continues to grow apace in 2022, aluminum prices could well continue moving upwards, with the possibility of occasional spikes due to a variety of kinds of bad news for the industry. But there are currently signs that the upward trend in price is slowing. The 2020 pandemic trend would put aluminum at around 3200 to 3300 by the end of 2021, but that doesn't currently look likely to me, barring a repeat catastrophic magnesium shortage. The 2021 trend would put aluminum at about 2800 by the end of the year, which is completely plausible, and somewhere almost exactly around 3200 by the end of April. As the growth trend in the price of aluminum will likely continue to slow, I will guess that if the current trend continues, that aluminum will be between 2900 and 3200 by the end of April. As the error bars are very large, and large movements in supply and demand are possible, I'll leave a wide margin for error.

Inflationary pressures. Supply chain pressures. Possible temporary mine closures due to Covid. Infrastructure plans will be discussed or announced by major economies, which will lead to increased speculation. China might however try to keep a lid on prices by announcing that they will sell of strategic stockpiles of commodities such aluminium.

We don't know how bad the winter in China will get. It's only October, and we're already seeing manufacturing problems. What happens in Jan and Feb, when the need for heat is largest? Will the trend continue upwards in 2022? I suspect prices will stay fairly high throughout winter and probably decline after that a bit, but I'm not sure. I'm casting a wide net in this forecast, as there is a lot of time between now and April 29.
